Comment: This command info is generated from fig
Name: br
Description: Broot lets you explore file hierarchies with a tree-like view, manipulate files, launch actions, and define your own shortcuts. broot is best launched as br: this shell function gives you access to more commands, especially cd. The br shell function is interactively installed on first broot launch. Flags and options can be classically passed on launch but also written in the configuration file. Each flag has a counter-flag so that you can cancel at command line a flag which has been set in the configuration file

Arguments.Name: --dates
Arguments.Description: Show the last modified date of files and directories

Arguments.Name: --no-dates
Arguments.Description: Don't show the last modified date

Arguments.Name: --show-git-info
Arguments.Description: Show git statuses on files and stats of repository

Arguments.Name: --no-show-git-info
Arguments.Description: Don't show git statuses on files nor stats

Arguments.Name: --git-status
Arguments.Description: Only show files having an interesting git status, including hidden ones

Arguments.Name: --show-gitignored
Arguments.Description: Show files which should be ignored according to git

Arguments.Name: --permissions
Arguments.Description: Show permissions with owner and group

Arguments.Name: --sizes
Arguments.Description: Show the sizes of files and directories. When this mode is on, children aren't shown so that the biggest entries at the selected level can be sorted first

Arguments.Name: --sort-by-count
Arguments.Description: Sort by count (only show one level of the tree)

Arguments.Name: --sort-by-date
Arguments.Description: Sort by date (only show one level of the tree)

Arguments.Name: --sort-by-size
Arguments.Description: Sort by size (only show one level of the tree)

Arguments.Name: --whale-spotting
Arguments.Description: Sort by size, show ignored and hidden files

Arguments.Name: --trim-root
Arguments.Description: Trim the root: remove elements which would exceed the screen size. This removes the scrollbar

Arguments.Name: --no-trim-root
Arguments.Description: Don't trim the root (still trim the deeper levels). A scrollbar may be used when there are too many elements to show on screen

Arguments.Name: --install
Arguments.Description: Install or reinstall the br shell function

Arguments.Name: --get-root
Arguments.Description: Ask for the current root of the remote broot

Arguments.Name: --color
Arguments.Description: Controls styling of the output (default: auto). If set to auto, all styling is removed when output is piped

Arguments.Name: --help
Arguments.Description: Prints a help page, with more or less the same content as this man page

Arguments.Name: --outcmd
Arguments.Description: Where to write a command if broot produces one

Arguments.Name: --cmd
Arguments.Description: Semicolon separated commands to execute on start of broot

Arguments.Name: --conf
Arguments.Description: Semicolon separated paths to specific config files

Arguments.Name: --height
Arguments.Description: Height to use if you don't want to fill the screen or for file export (by default the terminal height is used)

Arguments.Name: --out
Arguments.Description: Where to write the produced path, if any

Arguments.Name: --set-install-state
Arguments.Description: Set the installation state. This is mostly useful in installation scripts to override the normal installation process

Arguments.Name: --print-shell-function
Arguments.Description: Print to stdout the br function for the given shell. This can be used in your own installation process overriden the standard one

Arguments.Name: --send
Arguments.Description: Send commands to a remote broot then quits
